descr.p: "The Streak" is a popular song written, produced, and sung by Ray Stevens. It was released in 1974. "The Streak" capitalized on the then popular craze of streaking.

One of Stevens' most successful recordings, "The Streak" was his second number one on the Billboard Hot 100 singles chart in the USA, spending three weeks at the top in May 1974 and reached #3 on the Billboard Country singles chart. A major international hit it also reached #1 on the UK Singles Chart, spending a single week at the top of the chart in June 1974. In total it sold over 5 million copies internationally.

The song's story is a series of three "news flashes" featuring the "Action News Reporter" (Stevens) on the scenes of reported streaking events: at the supermarket, the gas station, and the basketball playoffs. The reporter interviews a man (also Stevens) who responds with his views of what happened. The responses contain several double entendres, and the man tries to warn his wife, Ethel, not to look ("Don't look, Ethel!"), but is always too late. After the third interview, the man sees the streaker again, but to his horror the streaker is joined by his wife, and the man changes his tune: "Ethel, you shameless hussy!".

"The Streak" is one of the songs referenced in another Ray Stevens tune, "Dudley Dorite of the Highway Patrol", in which Stevens is supposedly pulled over by a patrolman who believes, along with his friends and family, that Stevens is deliberately misrepresenting them in his songs. The patrolman specifically reminisces to Stevens about his wife, Ethel: "You remember Ethel, don't ya, boy? That 'shameless hussy'?" The theme of "Dudley Dorite" was later used as a central plot in Stevens' direct-to-video film, Get Serious, where Stevens (playing a fictionalized version of himself) encounters this supposed real-life Ethel, who expresses dismay at being portrayed as "some kind of Lady Godiva".

In the 2000s, the 1974 album Boogity-Boogitythat contained "The Streak" among other novelty songs was re-released in CD format along with Ray's 1973 album Nashvilleas a two album on one CD release on Collectables Records. The albums will be featured in a box set from Collectables Records entitled Only The Best of Ray Stevenswhich will house all of the vinyl on CD re-issues.
